metadata.description: Plant-based Singaporean dishes, featuring vegetables, tofu, and meat alternatives

recipes.name: Hakka Lei Cha (Thunder Tea Rice)
recipes.description: A classic Hakka dish of steamed rice topped with a medley of finely chopped vegetables, tofu, peanuts, and pickles, served with a vibrant green herbal tea soup made from ground herbs, tea leaves, nuts, and seeds. Popular in Singapore's hawker centres for its health benefits and unique flavor.
steps: Coarsely chop basil and mint. Heat oil in a pan, add garlic, stir until soft. Add basil, mint, and cilantro; stir-fry until bright green. Remove from pan.
In a blender, grind tea leaves and peppercorns. Add peanuts and sesame seeds; blend until finely ground.
Add the sautéed herbs and 1 cup cold water to the blender; blend until smooth.
Add 1 cup boiling water to the herb mixture and blend again until smooth. Pour into a pot, add remaining boiling water and salt, whisk to blend, and heat until hot.
Prepare all rice toppings: sauté vegetables, pan-fry tofu, chop peanuts and radish, fry anchovies if using.
To serve, arrange rice in bowls, top with each vegetable, tofu, peanuts, sesame seeds, radish, and anchovies in separate sections.
Serve with hot lei cha soup on the side. Diners may pour the soup over the rice and toss everything together before eating.
tips: Use a variety of fresh herbs for the lei cha paste for best flavor.
Each topping should be cooked and seasoned separately for distinct flavors.
Brown rice adds a nutty flavor and extra nutrition.
Omit anchovies for a vegetarian version.
recipes.origin: Hakka Lei Cha is a centuries-old dish brought to Singapore by Hakka immigrants. It is celebrated for its adaptability, health benefits, and the communal effort involved in its preparation.

recipes.name: Tahu Telur (Indonesian Beancurd Omelette)
recipes.description: A popular Malay-Indonesian hawker dish in Singapore, featuring deep-fried tofu and egg tower, served with a sweet-spicy peanut sauce, cucumber, and bean sprouts. Crispy on the outside, soft inside, and bursting with flavor.
steps: Cut tofu into cubes and pat dry. Beat eggs in a large bowl, then gently fold in tofu cubes.

Heat oil in a deep pan or wok. Pour the tofu-egg mixture into a round mold or directly into the oil, shaping into a tall 'tower' if possible. Fry until golden brown and crispy on all sides. Drain on paper towels.

For the peanut sauce: Blend or pound peanuts, garlic, and chilies into a coarse paste. In a saucepan, combine the paste with tamarind juice, kecap manis, sugar, water, and salt. Simmer until thickened, adjusting water for desired consistency.
To serve: Place the fried tofu-egg tower on a plate. Top with blanched bean sprouts, cucumber, and carrot. Generously spoon over the warm peanut sauce.
Garnish with fried shallots and coriander. Serve immediately.
tips: Use a metal ring mold for a tall, restaurant-style presentation, or simply fry as a flat omelette.
Kecap manis (sweet soy sauce) is essential for authentic flavor.
Adjust chili quantity for desired spiciness.
Best served fresh and hot for maximum crispiness.
recipes.source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore/Malay hawker stalls.
recipes.origin: Malay and Indonesian communities; a hawker favorite in Singapore, especially at Geylang Serai and food courts.

recipes.name: Vegetarian Fried Bee Hoon (Singapore Style)
recipes.description: A classic Singaporean vegetarian breakfast staple: stir-fried rice vermicelli with cabbage, mushrooms, tofu, carrots, and bean sprouts. Served at hawker centers and vegetarian stalls, often with curry gravy or sambal.

main.ginger: 1 small slice, grated or thinly sliced

preparation: Soak rice vermicelli in warm water for at least 15 minutes until semi-soft. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil in a large skillet or wok. Sauté garlic and ginger until aromatic.
Add carrot, mushrooms, and tofu. Sauté for 2-3 minutes. Add cabbage and a little soy sauce or salt. Sauté until almost cooked.
Add vermicelli and water, then all seasonings. Add bean sprouts and sauté until everything is evenly coated. Use chopsticks to help loosen the noodles. Cover and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Uncover and sauté until gravy is almost dried up and noodles are soft. Add water if needed. Adjust seasonings to taste.
Transfer to a plate and top with garnishes. Serve hot.
tips: Different brands of rice vermicelli absorb different amounts of water. Adjust as needed.
For a more moist version, add extra water and cover to steam briefly.
recipes.source: Adapted from Veggie Temptation, Wikipedia, and local hawker practice.
steps: Soak rice vermicelli in warm water for at least 15 minutes until semi-soft. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil in a large skillet or wok. Sauté garlic and ginger until aromatic.
Add carrot, mushrooms, and tofu. Sauté for 2-3 minutes. Add cabbage and a little soy sauce or salt. Sauté until almost cooked.
Add vermicelli and water, then all seasonings. Add bean sprouts and sauté until everything is evenly coated. Use chopsticks to help loosen the noodles. Cover and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Uncover and sauté until gravy is almost dried up and noodles are soft. Add water if needed. Adjust seasonings to taste.
Transfer to a plate and top with garnishes. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Vegetarian Lor Mee (Braised Noodles)
recipes.description: A vegetarian take on the Hokkien-Singaporean classic: thick yellow noodles in a rich, starchy braised gravy with mushrooms, tofu, and vegetables. Served with vinegar, garlic, and chili.
preparation: Heat oil in a pot. Sauté garlic, mushrooms, tofu, and carrot until fragrant.
Add vegetable stock, soy sauces, sugar, and pepper. Simmer 20 minutes.
Add bok choy. Stir in cornstarch slurry to thicken gravy.
Blanch noodles and divide into bowls. Ladle gravy and toppings over. Serve with vinegar, minced garlic, and chili.
tips: Add mock meat or gluten for extra protein.
Adjust gravy thickness to taste.
recipes.source: Adapted from Veggie Temptation, The MeatMen, and Singapore vegetarian stalls.
steps: Heat oil in a pot. Sauté garlic, mushrooms, tofu, and carrot until fragrant.
Add vegetable stock, soy sauces, sugar, and pepper. Simmer 20 minutes.
Add bok choy. Stir in cornstarch slurry to thicken gravy.
Blanch noodles and divide into bowls. Ladle gravy and toppings over. Serve with vinegar, minced garlic, and chili.

recipes.name: Thunder Tea Rice (Lei Cha Fan)
recipes.description: A Hakka heritage dish popular at Singapore vegetarian stalls: rice topped with assorted vegetables, tofu, peanuts, and served with a fragrant green tea and herb soup.

ingredients.rice: 2 cups cooked jasmine or brown rice

preparation: Prepare all vegetables and tofu. Stir-fry each topping separately with a little oil and salt until cooked. Set aside.
For soup: Blend tea leaves, herbs, peanuts, and sesame seeds with water until smooth. Simmer gently, season with salt.
To serve: Place rice in bowls, arrange toppings on top. Pour hot green tea soup over or serve on the side.
tips: Use a mix of herbs for the most aromatic soup.
Add more peanuts or seeds for a richer broth.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Veggie Temptation, and Singapore Hakka home kitchens.
steps: Prepare all vegetables and tofu. Stir-fry each topping separately with a little oil and salt until cooked. Set aside.
For soup: Blend tea leaves, herbs, peanuts, and sesame seeds with water until smooth. Simmer gently, season with salt.
To serve: Place rice in bowls, arrange toppings on top. Pour hot green tea soup over or serve on the side.

recipes.name: Sayur Lodeh (Vegetable Coconut Curry)
recipes.description: A classic Malay/Peranakan vegetable curry: assorted vegetables simmered in a fragrant coconut milk broth with lemongrass, galangal, and spices. Served with rice or lontong (compressed rice cakes).
preparation: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth.
Heat oil in a pot, sauté spice paste until fragrant.
Add vegetables, stir-fry 2–3 minutes. Add coconut milk, water, salt, and sugar. Simmer 20–25 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Add tofu puffs and tempeh, simmer 5 more minutes. Serve hot with rice or lontong.
tips: Use a mix of vegetables for best flavor and texture.
Serve with sambal for extra heat.
recipes.source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore Malay kitchens.
steps: Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth.
Heat oil in a pot, sauté spice paste until fragrant.
Add vegetables, stir-fry 2–3 minutes. Add coconut milk, water, salt, and sugar. Simmer 20–25 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Add tofu puffs and tempeh, simmer 5 more minutes. Serve hot with rice or lontong.

recipes.name: Lontong (Compressed Rice Cakes)
recipes.description: A staple accompaniment to sayur lodeh and festive Malay meals: rice cooked, compressed, and cut into firm cakes. Served with coconut curries, sambal, and serunding (spiced coconut).
preparation: Drain soaked rice. Boil in plenty of water until just cooked but still firm. Drain well.
Spread rice onto a tray, cool slightly. Pack tightly into banana leaf or plastic wrap, roll into a log, and secure ends.
Steam 1 hour until firm. Cool completely, then slice into thick rounds. Serve with sayur lodeh, sambal, and serunding.
tips: Use banana leaves for best flavor and aroma.
Let lontong cool fully before slicing for clean edges.
recipes.source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore Malay kitchens.
steps: Drain soaked rice. Boil in plenty of water until just cooked but still firm. Drain well.
Spread rice onto a tray, cool slightly. Pack tightly into banana leaf or plastic wrap, roll into a log, and secure ends.
Steam 1 hour until firm. Cool completely, then slice into thick rounds. Serve with sayur lodeh, sambal, and serunding.

recipes.name: Kedondong Salad (Ambarella Salad)
recipes.description: A refreshing Peranakan and Malay salad of shredded kedondong (ambarella), carrots, cucumber, and peanuts, tossed in a tangy, spicy dressing. Popular at Nyonya and Malay tables.
preparation: Combine all ingredients in a large bowl. Toss well to coat with dressing.
Let sit 10 minutes for flavors to meld. Serve chilled or at room temperature.
tips: Substitute green apple if kedondong is unavailable.
Add fried shallots for extra crunch.
recipes.source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
steps: Combine all ingredients in a large bowl. Toss well to coat with dressing.
Let sit 10 minutes for flavors to meld. Serve chilled or at room temperature.

recipes.name: Vadai (Indian-Style Savory Fritters)
recipes.description: A popular Indian-Singaporean snack: deep-fried savory fritters made from urad dal (black gram), spices, and curry leaves. Crispy outside, fluffy inside, often served with green chili or coconut chutney.
preparation: Drain soaked dal. Grind to a thick, coarse paste with minimal water.
Mix in onion, chili, curry leaves, cumin, salt, and baking soda.
Shape into small discs or rings. Fry in hot oil until golden and crisp. Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with green chili or coconut chutney.
tips: Do not add too much water when grinding dal.
Add chopped spinach or grated carrot for variation.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Indian stalls.
steps: Drain soaked dal. Grind to a thick, coarse paste with minimal water.
Mix in onion, chili, curry leaves, cumin, salt, and baking soda.
Shape into small discs or rings. Fry in hot oil until golden and crisp. Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with green chili or coconut chutney.

recipes.name: Chap Chye (Mixed Vegetable Stew)
recipes.description: A classic Peranakan and Chinese New Year dish: braised mixed vegetables with cabbage, mushrooms, bean curd sticks, glass noodles, and black fungus in a savory bean paste sauce.
preparation: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté garlic and bean paste until fragrant.
Add mushrooms, black fungus, carrot, and cabbage. Stir-fry 2–3 minutes.
Add bean curd sticks, glass noodles, soy sauce, sugar, and water. Simmer 30–40 minutes until vegetables are tender and flavors meld.
Serve hot with rice.
tips: Add lily buds or dried beancurd skin for extra texture.
Use vegetarian oyster sauce for more umami.
recipes.source: Adapted from Nyonya Cooking, The MeatMen, and Singapore Peranakan kitchens.
steps: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté garlic and bean paste until fragrant.
Add mushrooms, black fungus, carrot, and cabbage. Stir-fry 2–3 minutes.
Add bean curd sticks, glass noodles, soy sauce, sugar, and water. Simmer 30–40 minutes until vegetables are tender and flavors meld.
Serve hot with rice.
